item.title: [HADOOP-10141] Create an API to separate encryption key storage from applications
item.description:
As with the filesystem API, we need to provide a generic mechanism to support multiple key storage mechanisms that are potentially from third parties.

An additional requirement for long term data lakes is to keep multiple versions of each key so that keys can be rolled periodically without requiring the entire data set to be re-written. Rolling keys provides containment in the event of keys being leaked.

Toward that end, I propose an API that is configured using a list of URLs of KeyProviders. The implementation will look for implementations using the ServiceLoader interface and thus support third party libraries.

Two providers will be included in this patch. One using the credentials cache in MapReduce jobs and the other using Java KeyStores from either HDFS or local file system.

comments.comment:
The same thing was already proposed and implemented in the HADOOP-9331. This duplicates our work done.
The key management facilities such as KeyProvider were already there. We also provided KeyStoreKeyProvider as a basic implementation for retrieving keys from java KeyStore. If you do need any improvements, we can follow up and discuss based on HADOOP-9331 and close this proposal as duplicate.
This patch implements the API and provides two KeyProviders: User and Java KeyStore.
The description of HADOOP-9825 looks like it may have been intended to be similar in scope.

Jerry, the closest I could find to this jira was HADOOP-9825, which hasn't been worked on since it was created in August. Let's work together to get this committed so that we can use it as the basis for the upstream work.

This is good and concise work.

Couple comments:

  • JksProvider - maybe should be renamed to JceksProvider or more generically as KeystoreProvider as the implementation currently cannot use a JKS type store
  • A keystore provider that doesn't depend on Hadoop internals may be also desirable
  • I like the extension of the FS approach for paths for including others - like the UserProvider
Owen, please check the design document attached in HADOOP-9331 and the patch attached in its subtask HADOOP-9333 for what have been proposed and done.

Jerry, the part of HADOOP-9333 that does similar things doesn't address the requirements:

  • No API for creating, accessing, or managing the keys.
  • No versioning of the keys.
  • No use of the ServiceLoader API to provide 3rd party extensions for key management.

Let's work together to get this committed and we can make forward progress.

Updated patch:

  • Renamed JksProvider to JavaKeyStoreProvider
  • Changed URL scheme for JavaKeyStoreProvider to jceks. If we want to support other keystore types in the future, it should be relatively easy to add additional schemes to the JavaKeyStoreProvider.

That's great. Generic provider for java keystores and specific support for jceks. Clear and open for extension in the future.
Thanks, Owen!

Owen, the way this JIRA is going really confused me.
Just as mentioned, "the part of HADOOP-9333 that does similar things doesn't address the requirements". Why not improve based the existing work to satisfiy the requirements other than starting a separate one? since HADOOP-9333 has not closed yet.

The name/version format makes it unsafe for URLs, xml etc. Would it make sense or be useful to pick a separator that is url safe? Since we are exposing key-version to users, it may be backward incompatible to change it later.

Jitendra,
That's a good point, I changed the separator to '@' which is clean in URIs, but still reads well. I also added a findProvider utility to look through a list of providers to find the right one and updated the default to AES/CTR/NoPadding.
